segments.text: translation night time suddenly she awoke in a panic someone was knocking on the entrance door in front of her room for a moment she thought she might be dreaming she listened again but someone indeed knocked persistently on the door
It was three in the morning.
She shivered.
Who could it be?
She rose from the mattress barefoot, wearing Dan's t-shirt that reached almost to her knees, approached the door with small steps, and cautiously and quietly asked, Who is it?
Can you open up?
I'm from Dan's work.
Gideon sent me.
Now, in the middle of the night, she asked, feeling fear creeping in.
Yes, please open up.
He almost pleaded.
She carefully opened the door.
A young man stood before her, slightly insecure, hesitant, not knowing what to say.
He stammeringly explained that he was just the driver and was supposed to take her somewhere, not able to say where.
Now, at three in the morning, what happened, she asked.
I have no idea, he replied.
I've been on the road for almost two hours, and we have at least another hour to go."
Destination, she thought, as if she too had been recruited into Dan's work.
Look, she told him.
I have a sleeping baby.
I can't just pull him out of bed at three in the morning.
You must explain a bit more.
But Gideon said you'd immediately understand and there'd be no issue.
He said you communicate with him and will already sense it.
I have no idea what he's talking about.
I just need to get you to the destination.
God, what a fool.
The sparrows have been crying for days and I'm still asking for explanations, she realized.
Sit!"
she ordered him.
She went into her room and within a second was dressed in her own pants and t-shirt, watched her face, braided her hair, and dressed Ben-Ben while he was still sleeping.
She packed a few necessary items into her bag and only then, with Ben-Ben already in her arms, wrapped in a thin blanket.
Get she face the young driver.
He got up from where he was seated and went outside, with her following silently.
The roads were empty, darkness surrounded them, and only the noise of the car could be heard in the background.
It was an ordinary white car.
She sat in the back seat, with Ben Ben's head resting on her lap.
As they continued driving, frightening thoughts began to gnaw at her.
She leaned her head against the seat, tightly closing her eyes, trying to drive the thoughts away, and suddenly saw him lying on a bed, pale as chalk.
She opened her eyes with a slight moan.
Where is he taking me?
What happened to Dan?
She cried inside, feeling tears welling up.
Please, you can't die on me after all these long months.
I love you so much, and you have an amazing son waiting for you, kissing your picture.
Please, please.
Then she pulled herself together suddenly, gathering herself from all those thoughts.
Knowing she had to regain the composure and self-control she always displayed.
He needed her strong, not whining.
She felt her patients fading, only wishing they would arrive at the destination.
She must have dozed off in mental exhaustion when suddenly the car stopped.
She straightened herself, clutching Ben-Ben protectively, trying to understand where they were.
It was a parking lot.
The three of them got out of the vehicle.
and the driver led her to a side door that opened into a long and narrow corridor at the end of which they entered an elevator.
Only then did she notice the small direction signs in the elevator.
Floor A, internal medicine.
Floor B, urology.
Floor C, intensive care.
They were in a hospital.
They were going to C.
For a moment, she felt her heart stop.
Then its beats went wild, losing control, like Tom Tom's pounding inside her.

She held on to Ben Ben tightly, almost clinging to him to avoid fainting, exited the elevator and took a few steps after the young driver until she saw Gideon standing at the entrance to one of the rooms.
He approached her and placed a hand on her shoulder.
He'll be OK, he said.
The main thing is we got him out and he's here.
Hearing but not hearing.
She handed him the sleeping Ben-Ben, pushed the room door open and entered.
Once she saw her Dan pale as chalk, tubes attached to him, a bandage covering part of his head, his bare chest also bandaged.
Her legs trembled and she forced herself to come a little closer.
He was still unshaved like in her dreams.
A few more wrinkles on his forehead, but he was all there.

She touched his hand, stroking it, and slowly, without realizing it, climbed onto his bed and lay beside him, snuggled against his body, curling into a fetal position, wanting to feel his body heat to know it wasn't another dream, to know he was really there, that he was back.
Tears filled her eyes.
Silent tears ran down her cheeks.
Her eyes open, looking at Dan with great love, and only wishing he would open his eyes too.
Gideon carefully opened the room door, holding his breath at the sight of her curled up with Dan.
A great excitement spread over him.
He stood close to them, and Ben-Ben asleep in his arms.
This is what love looks like, he thought.
A minute later, the doctor also entered the room.
He was in his forties with a sporty appearance and a determined look.
She turned to them, wiping her eyes with the back of her hand, carefully getting off the bed, extending her hands to Gideon and taking Ben Ben from him.
Sit, the doctor said.
Dan was seriously injured, but we managed to stabilize him.
His body is a bit weak from the dengue.
He was sick with some time ago.
It's a common fever in the Caribbean.
And when it passes, it leaves the body very weak for a while.
It might take a little time, but he will recover.
He's still unconscious after the surgery to remove the bullets from his chest.
They missed his heart by just a few centimeters.
I understand he didn't miss much either, he added with a smile.
She had no idea what he was talking about.
Gideon cleared his throat towards him.
The doctor suddenly realized he had said too much.
All this time, she sat upright, as if listening, in the chair beside Dan's bed, Ben Ben asleep in her arms.
And suddenly, as if taking command returned to her, she said, we have to inform Naomi and David and also Noga.
We've already informed them, said Gideon, and also the unit commander.
Naomi and David are flying to Israel, and Noga will arrive in the morning.
I forbade her to drive in the dark.
Look, this room is side by side and almost hidden, but next to the doctor's room.
They will all take care of you and everything you need.
Moishek, the driver, is also staying here, and I'm leaving you some money if you want to buy something for you or Ben Ben.
She looked at him, puzzled, Gideon, it's kind of you, but I really don't need anything, and I have money in my purse.
Send Moishek, the driver, home to sleep.
He's roamed the roads enough all night.
I'll nap with Ben Ben on the chair beside his bed.
It seems wide enough for both of us.
In her heart, she thought it was clear she couldn't close her eyes out of excitement and eagerness to see that he was okay.
Nonetheless, she felt a great happiness and relief spreading through her, as if a huge burden had been lifted from her, knowing she was no longer alone, that she was together.
Apparently, she did nap a little on the chair, with Ben-Ben in her arms, and she opened her eyes only with the entry of the doctor and a nurse into the room.
The nurse handed her a hot cup of coffee.
Hi, I'm Gila, she smiled warmly at her.
Thank you," Leora replied, taking the cup from her hands.
Tell me, can the bed be lowered a little?
Yes, of course, Gila answered.
For the little one?
She understood immediately.
She wants Ben-Ben to be able to see Daddy Dan.
Gila gently pulled the handle meant for that purpose, lowering the bed slowly.
Dan's face was calm, and a pinkish hue began to return to his pale complexion.
She longed to shave his beard, to restore his true image, to see his cheekbones again.
When is he supposed to start waking up?
She asked.
Look, the doctor said cautiously.
It could take hours, but it might also take a few days.
The body has its own ways of dealing with such trauma situations.
This may seem strange to you, but you can talk to him.
It turns out that when they wake up, they tell that they heard as they were spoken to, and it encouraged them to awaken.
It's not strange to her at all, she thought.
She's been talking to him, to him for hours.
In any case, there's nothing to worry about, even if it takes a while.
Eventually, he'll be completely fine.
I understand he has pleasant surprises waiting for him when he opens his eyes, which will certainly expedite his recovery.
This doctor knows everything.

Suddenly, she remembered that he had slipped out that Dan did not miss, and she was curious to know exactly what had happened, and where was that Spanish-speaking place she had discovered in her dreams.
While still standing beside his bed, the door burst open and Noga stood at the entrance.
She fell on her neck and burst into tears.
Noga, don't cry.
Everything's okay.
He'll be okay.
See, he's here.
He's just asleep a bit until he recovers.
After calming down a little and not before stroking Dan's face in hand, she noticed Ben Ben sleeping on the chair.
She picked him up in her arms, inhaling his scent and whispered to him, how Aunt Noga missed you.
Then turned back to Leora and told her, how good we are at crying on each other's shoulders.
That's probably what sisters are for.
Leora replied with a half smile, hugging her.
As if sensing the commotion around him, Ben Ben opened his eyes, a smile spread across his sweet face.
He looked at Noga in surprise and said, Duda, then he looked around, reaching out to his mother, and she took him from Noga, standing him next to Dan's bed.
The child stood and looked at the bearded man with the bandage on his head, not recognizing in him the father he knew from the picture.
He glanced at his mother in apprehension and clung to her leg, probably frightened by the bandage and the unfamiliar room full of tubes.
Noga, she said decisively, please take Benven to the canteen.
Buy him a chocolate drink and maybe something to eat.
There's something I urgently need to do.
Noga took Benben's hand and left the room with him.
Despite the curiosity that arose within her, she did not press Leora.
She apparently knows what she's doing.
She thought to herself.
Now, left alone with Dan, Leora pressed the nurse's bell.
Within a moment, Gila, the morning nurse, was by her side.
I need to shave him, she told Gila.
Could you get me some shaving tools?
The nurse looked at her intently.
Give me a few minutes, and I'll arrange everything.
And if you struggle, I'll help.
When a small bowl of water was by her side, foam and a razor in her hand, she began to shave his beard carefully.
Gila, the nurse, stood beside her, watching in admiration.
I just remember my father standing and shaving in the mornings.
I've seen it so many times that I must remember all the steps, she explained.
Given his beard was quite thick, it wasn't so simple.
She had to repeat each area repeatedly, and finally when Omi's stubble was left on his cheeks, she soaked them again and started to shave him smoothly.
With each stroke of shaving, his handsome features were revealed to her, his cheekbones and his chin dimple.
She released the Dan who had appeared in her dreams from the disguise he had to wear, bringing back her beloved Dan.
Now it only remained for him to open his eyes and smile at her.
The nurse looked at her with open affection.
Now I understand why you were eager to shave him.
He's simply a charming guy.
We'll need to ensure he gets out of this as quickly as possible so he can see how much love surrounds him.
Once the nurse left, taking with her all the shaving tools,
And Leora was left alone with him again.

She could no longer resist and lay down beside him again, wrapping an arm around him, tucking her head into the crook of his neck, inhaling the scent of shaving cream and feeling tears rise in her again.
You must wake up, Dan.
Open your eyes.
With that warm brown inside them, meet your amazing son.
I want you to be awake when Mom Naomi and Dad David arrive.
Please, Dan," she nearly pleaded.
I have so much to tell you.
Slowly her eyes closed and she fell asleep exhausted beside him.
Noga sacked in the canteen with Ben-Ben on her lap.
This child brings solace to the soul, she fought.
He was sipping chocolate through a straw prepared for him, occasionally resting the cup and eating the omelet and rings of green cucumber beside it, with a fork on his own.
A brilliant child, she mused.
On the table lay a newspaper from that morning.
Its main headline declared across the width of the page, the capture of a wanted Nazi criminal amidst a shootout on one of the islands in Central America.
Well done, she thought, and suddenly cold swept over her body and in a moment.
She understood the connection between her brother lying injured in his room and this operation.
She almost couldn't wait until Ben-Ben finished his meal and then held his hand and hurried him back to Dan's room, the newspaper in her hand.
She forcefully opened the room door, wanting to tell Leora about the newspaper's discovery but stopped in her tracks.
seeing her sister-in-law, sprawled, embracing beside him, asleep.
She put her finger to her lips, signaling Ben-Ben to be quiet.
He looked at her in wonder, then at the bed where his mother lay beside the man now without a beard and joyfully declared, Baba Dan.
Without any hesitation, he climbed onto the bed, snuggled between his mother and father, drew his small body close, held his hand and said again, Baba Dan.
The child closed his eyes, imitating his mother's action, and lo and behold, within a few minutes, calm sleep fell over him too as he lay between the warmth of his father and his mother.
Noga sank with depleted energy onto the chair beside the bed.
Tears ran down her cheeks at the touching sight.
Her wounded, pale brother, as he returned to being the brother she remembers after his shave, and his family sprawled beside him in great love.
The newspaper still in her hands.
She re-read its headline.
In any case, the world must not be informed of what happened.
And anyway, there is not much information in the article.
Just the bottom line of the outcome announcing a long and complex mission lasting more than a year and ending in great success.
The room door was pushed open again, and at the entrance stood Mom Naomi and Dad David with the unit commander who had brought them from the airport.
Three of them stood there, speechless at the scene before them.
Dan, the large one beside his mini-image, and his girl from the pink house, embraced all three, sleeping peacefully.
Noga slept on the chair, the newspaper limped on her lap,
and the whole room broadcasted a calm mingled with the fatigue of those whose long hours of sleep were denied them.
Now they could relax a bit.
Naomi approached the bed, reached out, and stroked her son's face with great love, only then moving to the small face of his son, sleeping beside him.
She gently moved a lock of hair away from her face.
And all the time, tears didn't stop flowing from her eyes.
David approached her and hugged her shoulders, not hiding the tears that had also risen in his eyes.
It's all right, Neomila.
It's all right now, he whispered to her.
The unit commander stood a bit off.
The whole way he had told them about little Ben-Ben, saying he is the most special baby I've ever met.
And besides, he's a complete copy of his father, and only his eyes are as blue as those of his mother.
Now his heart goes out to Naomi, falling apart before his eyes after all the months where she was worried for her son's fate.
I want so much to hug this little one," she whispered.
See how he looks like him, David said.
He's exactly Dan when he was little.
Wait until he opens his eyes, insisted the commander.
Then you'll see that in his gaze he is entirely his mother.
